facts.text: Mining lease granted by the 1st respondent (alleged to have been created by the 2nd respondent) in favour of Haricharan Singh J.D. Co. on 7-9-1950.
Sum of Rs. 80,000/- paid to the 1st respondent in pursuance of the lease.
1st respondent was a Limited Company created by the 2nd respondent.
Earlier lease in respect of the same property in favour of respondents 3 and 4 which expired on 4-4-1950.
Haricharan Singh J.D. Co. later changed its name to Kuju Collieries Ltd., the appellants.
Plaintiff did not get possession of the leased property and instituted suit for recovery of possession along with mesne profits and in the alternative for refund of Rs. 80,000/- and other sums.
Present appeal concerned only with the amount of Rs. 80,000/- payable by 1st respondent.

1st and 2nd respondents took stand that 1st respondent was not created by 2nd respondent, lease was by 1st respondent, amount paid to 1st respondent alone, leased properties handed over to plaintiff, not aware of resistance by respondents 3 and 4.
During pendency of appeal, respondents 2 and 3 died and their legal representatives have not been brought on record.
Appellant not claiming relief against other respondents except 1st respondent.
After institution of suit, Bihar Land Reforms Act came into force; any lessee working a mine became direct lessee under the State; plaintiff not working mines, so claim for possession unenforceable.
Appellant confined claim to Rs. 80,000/- as payable by 1st respondent.

Trial Court held plaintiff in mining business, consulted lawyers, lease deed by solicitors; Mineral Concession Rules 1949 rendered salami payment illegal, lease illegal; no relief under s.65 Contract Act; suit dismissed.
Patna High Court on appeal held neither s.65 nor s.72 Contract Act applied; affirmed dismissal.
Plaintiff had no certificate of approval from State Government as required under Rule 45 Mineral Concession Rules 1949.
Lease deed contained stipulation for payment of premium (salami), prohibited under Rule 49 Mineral Concession Rules 1949.
Plaintiff already in mining business, consulted lawyers and solicitors; no ignorance of law.
Mineral Concession Rules came into force on 25-10-1949; lease on 7-9-1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.65 of the Indian Contract Act applies to entitle the plaintiff to refund of Rs.80,000/- paid under a mining lease that was void ab initio due to violation of Mineral Concession Rules 1949 prohibiting salami and requiring certificate of approval.
Whether the lease agreement was discovered to be void or became void subsequently, or was void at inception with knowledge of both parties.

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled to refund of Rs.80,000/- under s.65 Contract Act as lease void.

respondent_arguments.text: 1st respondent not created by 2nd respondent; lease by 1st respondent; amount paid to 1st alone; possession handed over; not responsible for resistance by others; plaintiff not entitled to relief.

court_reasoning.text: S.65 distinguishes between agreement discovered to be void (void ab initio but discovered later) and contract becoming void subsequently; does not apply where both parties knew at inception it was unlawful and void.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parties knew lease illegal due to salami prohibition and no approval certificate; plaintiff experienced in mining, consulted lawyers; in pari delicto.

court_reasoning.text: Lease void under s.4 Mines and Minerals Act 1948 and Rules 45, 49 as no approval certificate, salami charged; void at inception, not discovered later.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff had no ignorance of law.

court_reasoning.text: S.65 not applicable to knowingly illegal agreements; courts do not assist parties in pari delicto.
court_reasoning.key_observation: References to Privy Council, High Court decisions approving this view.

court_reasoning.text: Neither s.70 nor s.72 applies as payment not lawful, not under mistake or coercion.

holdings.text: S.65 Contract Act does not apply to agreements void ab initio due to known illegality where parties in pari delicto.
Mining lease void under Mines and Minerals Act and Rules from inception; no restitution under s.65 as not discovered subsequently.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harnath Kaur v. Inder Bahadur Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Explains distinction in s.65 between agreements discovered void and contracts becoming void.
S.65 applies where voidness discovered subsequently even if ab initio void without prior knowledge; not for known illegal purposes where in pari delicto.
S.65 requires invalidity discovered subsequent to making; not for parties knowing illegality from beginning.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ramagya Prasad Gupta Ors v. Shri Murli Prasad Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Quoted with approval observations from Budhulal case on s.65.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: S.65 does not apply to knowingly illegal void agreements; s.72 also not applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: No mining lease granted contrary to rules; such lease void.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires certificate of approval; no premium/salami chargeable; violations render lease void.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Land Reforms Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Lessee working mine becomes direct lessee of State; affected possession claim.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the decisions of the Trial Court and Patna High Court dismissing the suit for refund of Rs.80,000/-, holding that s.65 of the Contract Act does not apply as the lease was void ab initio with knowledge of illegality by both parties who were in pari delicto.

key_quotes.text: "When an agreement is discovered to be void, or when a contract becomes void, any person who has received any advantage under such agreement or contract is bound to restore it, or to make compensation for it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.65 Contract Act and explains its scope.

key_quotes.text: "The section by using the words 'when an agreement is discovered to be void' means nothing more or less than when the plaintiff comes to know or finds out that the agreement is void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Budhulal case; clarifies 'discovered' implies subsequent knowledge.

key_quotes.text: "Courts do not assist a person who comes with unclean hands. In such cases, the defendant possesses at advantage conditio defendentis."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle of in pari delicto barring relief.
